awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  ABI Innovation:  Algorithms for recovering root architecture from 3D imaging
awd_abstract_narration:
Roots, the "hidden" half of the plant, play many critical roles in the plant's development such as the uptake of water and nutrients, providing anchorage, and stabilizing the soil. These functions, in turn, are closely associated with the root architecture. Quantifying root architecture is not only a fundamental aspect of plant science but is a critical component in crop breeding for sustainable agriculture. Recent advances in 3D imaging (e.g., CT and MRI) have made it possible to capture 3D root structures in natural growing environments and monitor their growth over time. Unfortunately, the potential of the imaging techniques has been largely held back by the lack of effective computational tools for interpreting the images and distilling biological insights. This project, to be conducted by a group of computer scientists, mathematicians, and biologists across three institutes in the St. Louis region, aims at developing efficient and robust computational methods for automated analysis of root architecture from 3D images. The research looks a step ahead of the current cutting edge phenotype data collection, to how we will derive accurate representations of growing root systems, and therefore gain insight into the plant phenome. The team is committed to providing training to more than ten students over the course of the project, leveraging the existing NSF REU programs at two of the institutes. The team will pursue outreach activities not only within the research communities but also locally in the St. Louis area with a focus on grade schools.

Deriving root architecture from 3D images involves a number of technically challenging tasks, including inferring individual roots from a segmented image, reconstructing their branching structure, and tracking the architecture in a time series of segmented images. This research draws from, and extends upon, methods from computer graphics and computational geometry to address these tasks. Specifically, the research will develop three novel classes of methods. Given a noise-ridden root segmentation, the first class of methods produces a curve skeleton that captures the topology and branching structure of the root system. The second class then uses the curve skeleton to automatically infer architectural components such as the root hierarchy and types. The third class improves the accuracy of the algorithms in the 1rst two classes by utilizing a sequence of segmentations and further annotates the root architecture with a time function. These algorithms enable the extraction of detailed root traits for root phenotyping, and both the algorithms and traits will be evaluated by a suite of representative real-world imaging data.
Besides the design of automatic algorithms, a graphical software will be prototyped that offers fast and interactive means to inspect and edit the results produced by the algorithms. The software will be tested by biologists in the team and freely distributed to the research community.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project aims at enhancing computational capabilities to analyze plant root traits from segmented 3D root images. The intellectual merit lies in the development of novel algorithms that address three aspects of the image-to-trait pipeline. First, we designed algorithms for reducing artifacts of the segmented images, particularly topological errors in the form of isolated components, redundant loops, and spurious interior voids. These artifacts arose due to the limited resolution or contrast of 3D imaging. If left untreated, they can significantly affect the accuracy of downstream analysis. Second, building upon the topological denoising techniques, we developed a complete pipeline (called TopoRoot) for inferring detailed architectural traits of roots from 3D images. Third, we developed an algorithm for consistently denoising a sequence of 3D volumes capturing the growth of a root system. This algorithm paves the way for analyzing fine-grained dynamic and growth traits in 3D time-series imaging of plant roots.


The TopoRoot pipeline makes a significant step forward in closing the gap between 3D imaging and root phenotyping. Unlike existing root analysis methods that are either limited to coarse-grained root characteristics (e.g., volume, depth, average root shape) or designed for seedling roots, our pipeline offers, for the first time, the shape and hierarchy level of individual roots of a complex root system such as a mature root crown. Consequently our research has the potential to offer biologists new insights into the growth and function of plants. In addition, the algorithms for reducing topological noise in 3D volumes are applicable to a broad range of biomedical imaging efforts where the images may suffer from noise and ambiguity. The TopoRoot pipeline, as well as all algorithms developed in this project are freely distributed on Github to benefit the biological community at large. The team has collectively trained over a dozen undergraduate students, master and PhD students, and postdocs over the course of the project, more than half of whom are female. The outcome of the project has been disseminated to both computer science and biology communities through numerous conference presentations, seminars, invited talks, and keynotes.
